Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic Biomaterial System For Creating Spatiotemporal Mechanical Forces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Part: This project will investigate and develop a new dynamic tissue engineering scaffold, harnessing state of the art knowledge in optical wave-front engineering, which will be able to produce diverse force types. The work will focus on producing scaffolds that can generate engineered spatiotemporal mechanical forces using near infrared irradiation. The three-pronged strategy that will be used in the fabrication of this dynamic scaffold system consists of (i) localized heating enabled by patterned illumination, (ii) an enlarged surface area resulting from pixelated post topography fabricated by imprinting technology, and (iii) an engineered comb-like porous structure with CNT reinforcement. This dynamic cell-seeding niche can provide physical forces varying in time and space to mimic some aspects of embryogenesis in a manner not previously possible. It will provide a platform for studying the effect of mechanical forces on cell fate. For this study, the effect of mechanical forces on the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells along a hepatocyte lineage will be investigated for the first time.

Non-Technical Part: The proposed new dynamic scaffold, harnessing state of the art knowledge in optical wave front engineering, will be able to deliver diverse forces to living cells. It will help to improve our knowledge of the role that mechanical forces play on tissue development and regeneration, thus facilitating controlled stem cell differentiation into specific tissues and organs. The platform can be extended for multiple cell type seeding in spatially predefined regions to facilitate stem cell differentiation. Applying fundamental knowledge of materials synthesis, mechanical characterization, and optical manipulation to life science and health will broaden the appeal of materials science and engineering to the diverse UC Merced student constituency that includes large Hispanic and Hmong populations. The grassroots outreach will include (i) a concerted effort to recruit nationally for underrepresented students by providing summer internship opportunities and encouraging participation in this research through independent study or a Materials Capstone Design course, and (ii) graduate students as well as faculty members giving public lectures and interactive presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The project goal is to create a mechanoresponsive material platform that can produce a variety of types of mechanical forces with high spatiotemporal precision. One specific aim is to provide time- and position- specific forces to mimic mechanical forces involved in embryonicdevelopment. This platform therefore enables fundamental investigation of the effect of force on stem cell differentiation as an example. Major findings/accomplishments are elaborated below.  

 

1. Temperature responsive polymer systems

We have identified two material systems that can generate mechanical forces in response to minute temperature fluctuations around human body temperature. One is based on breaking and reforming hydrogen bonds between water and the hydrophilic segment of a polymer hydrogel. Upon thermal stimulation, hydrogen bonds break, leading to the transition of polymer from a swollen state to a de-swollen state, thus causing a large volume shrinkage. Utilizing this phenomenon and employing fundamental concepts from chemistry, materials science, and nanoscale fabrication, we have constructed a near infrared (NIR) responsive bilayer system and demonstrated that liver stem cells can be stretched and compressed with spatiotemporal control by NIR irradiation. This system requires water to generate the needed strain forces. Water can readily scatter a small and well-defined NIR stimulating point source. Consequently, the resulting mechanical forces become much more diffused in comparison to the diameter of the NIR stimulus. Furthermore, large-scale conformational changes of polymer molecules together with water diffusing in and out, render limited cycle performance and innate slow response. 

The other material system is based on breaking and reforming hydrogen bonds within a small part of a polymer repeat unit. It only involves breaking intramolecular hydrogen bonds together with rotations of a few single bonds at a submolecular level. Highly reproducible forces can be generated. Water is no longer required. Using patterned polymer structure with a refractive index close to 1.7,  a more confined NIR and consequent photothermal stimuli can produce mechanical forces at a pre-defined location.

 

2. Photothermal response

            It is known that light offers high spatiotemporal precision. To provide time- and position-specific forces, we have fabricated composite materials that use carbon allotropes as dopants to promote photothermal effect. Comparing different types of carbon nanotubes and 2D graphene, few-walled carbon nanotubes (FWCNTs) offer the combination of high NIR photon absorption and mechanical reinforcement without retarding molecular movements. In contrast, 2D graphene acts as a barrier for polymer mechano-response noticeably.  Upon patterned NIR irradiation generated by a spatial light modulator, FWCNTs can efficiently absorb and convert NIR photon energy into thermal energy, producing a localized strain force that can be transmitted onto cells.

 

3. Optical setup

            We have developed a comprehensive optical apparatus that consists of three key components. One is a spatial light modulator coupled with an NIR light source and appropriate optics to deliver patterned NIR with a lateral resolution down to 5 microns. The second component is a fluorescence imaging setup that measures surface temperature profiles at a lateral resolution of 2 microns. The third is a bright field imaging system that allows monitoring of morphology changes caused by the force generated by the temperature-responsive polymer.

 

Broader impacts

 Applying fundamental knowledge of materials synthesis, mechanical characterization, and optical manipulation to life science and health provides a concrete multidisciplinary educational experience for all levels. This project has trained one postdoctoral associate and four graduate students (three from underrepresented groups). It has trained six undergraduate students, all from underrepresented groups. Three previous undergraduate trainees are pursuing graduate studies, and one Hispanic female has received a MS and now working at Intel.  The research has been integrated into course development. A lab module related to NIR temperature responsive polymers has been created. The lecture part was incorporated into the ?Polymer? course and the lab session will be offered through our ?Nanofabrication? course in 2020.

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2018
Modified by: Jennifer Lu

Image
  • We have designed and fabricated a nanocomposite substrate that can deliver spatially and temporally defined mechanical forces onto cells.
